Problem:
Consider a signal processing system wherein time-series data \\( x(t) \\) is transformed by a convolution with a kernel function \\( h(t) \\). The transformed signal \\( y(t) \\) is given by the convolution integral \\( y(t) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} x(\\tau)h(t - \\tau)d\\tau \\). We explore the impact of the Laplace Transform on this convolution and its causal inference under several scenarios.

If, after the convolution and before applying the Laplace Transform, an additional linear time-invariant system \\( g(t) \\) affects the signal generating \\( y'(t) = y(t) * g(t) \\), then does the Laplace Transform of the new output \\( \\mathcal{L}(y'(t)) \\) solely depend on the original data \\( \\mathcal{L}(x(t)) \\)?
Explanation: The introduction of \\( g(t) \\) as an intervention modifies the output by an additional convolution, making \\( \\mathcal{L}(y'(t)) = \\mathcal{L}(y(t)) \\cdot \\mathcal{L}(g(t)) \\), and hence, the resulting transform is dependent on \\( g(t) \\) as well as \\( x(t) \\) and \\( h(t) \\), illustrating dependent transformation dynamics.

Do not provide any final answer to the question. Output strictly in JSON format: {"causal_relation": "<concise natural-language causal description>"}.
causal_map_integration: The input signal x(t) causally influences the transformed signal y(t) through convolution with h(t), which in turn is affected by the linear time-invariant system g(t) to produce y'(t). The Laplace Transform of y'(t) depends on both the Laplace Transform of y(t) and g(t), and ultimately on x(t).
